choices.text: Vesicoureteral Reflux (VUR) Grade I; observation with antibiotic prophylaxis
Vesicoureteral Reflux (VUR) Grade II; antibiotic prophylaxis and observation
Vesicoureteral Reflux (VUR) Grade III; surgical correction
Vesicoureteral Reflux (VUR) Grade IV; ureteral reimplantation

questions.text: A 3-year-old female presents with recurrent febrile urinary tract infections (UTIs). A voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) reveals reflux of urine into the renal pelvis, but there is no dilation of the renal pelvis or ureter. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the recommended management for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A (Grade I VUR; observation with antibiotic prophylaxis): Correct. Grade I VUR involves reflux into the ureter without dilation. It's managed with observation and antibiotic prophylaxis.

Option B (Grade II VUR; antibiotic prophylaxis and observation): Incorrect. Grade II VUR involves reflux into the renal pelvis, requiring monitoring, not surgery.

Option C (Grade III VUR; surgical correction): Incorrect. Grade III VUR requires prophylaxis, surgery is only needed for recurrent infections or renal scarring.

Option D (Grade IV VUR; ureteral reimplantation): Incorrect. Grade IV VUR involves more severe reflux but would not be appropriate for this case based on the VCUG findings.

Management:

  • Grades I-II: Typically managed with observation or lowdose antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent UTIs.
  • Grade III: Antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended, with surgical intervention considered if there are recurrent UTIs or renal scarring.
  • Grades IV-V: Often require surgical correction, such as ureteral reimplantation, to prevent renal damage.

Key Takeaways:

  • Grade I VUR requires observation and antibiotic prophylaxis.
  • Surgical intervention is reserved for higher grades (IV-V) or recurrent infections.

Tags:

Topic: VUR

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 20 page number:282

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with jejunal atresia following presentation with bilious vomiting and abdominal distention. Based on the clinical findings and imaging, the child is found to have multiple atresias in the jejunum. What is the most likely classification of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A (Type I: Membranous atresia): Incorrect. Type I is characterized by a thin membrane covering the lumen, which can be seen as a partial obstruction in the jejunum. It does not involve multiple atresias.

Option B (Type II: Fibrous cord connecting blind ending segments): Incorrect. Type II involves a fibrous cord connecting two blind-ended segments of the bowel, but it is not associated with multiple atresias as seen in this case.

Option C (Type III: Mesenteric gap between blind ending segments): Incorrect. Type III shows a mesenteric gap between two blind-ending bowel segments, but it does not involve multiple atresias.

Option D (Type IV: Multiple atresias ("string of sausages")): Correct. Type IV involves multiple jejunal atresias, often described as the "string of sausages" appearance on imaging. This matches the clinical presentation of the child with multiple atresias.

Key Points:

  • Jejunal atresia is a congenital defect in the jejunum, leading to intestinal obstruction, typically presenting with bilious vomiting and abdominal distension in neonates.
  • Type IV jejunal atresia involves multiple atretic segments of the jejunum, which appear as a "string of sausages" on imaging.
  • Treatment involves surgical correction with bowel resection and anastomosis, depending on the type and location of the atresia.

Tags:

Topic: Pediatric Surgery, Jejunal Atresia

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Part 2, Chapter 18, Page number:266

choices.text: Malrotation with volvulus; Upper GI contrast study

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with sudden onset of episodic abdominal pain, vomiting, and red currant jelly stools. On examination, a sausage-shaped mass is palpated in the right upper quadrant. The child also demonstrates a positive Dance sign. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the best diagnostic tool to confirm it?
questions.solution:
Option A (Acute appendicitis; CT scan): Incorrect. While acute appendicitis can cause abdominal pain and vomiting, it typically does not present with red currant jelly stools, a palpable sausage-shaped mass, or a positive Dance sign. CT imaging can help diagnose appendicitis but is not the best choice for this case.

Option B (Intussusception; Ultrasound): Correct. The classic triad of sudden onset of abdominal pain, vomiting, and red currant jelly stools, along with the palpable sausage-shaped mass and positive Dance sign, points to intussusception. Ultrasound is the preferred diagnostic tool and shows the "target sign" or "doughnut sign," which is highly suggestive of intussusception.

Option C (Acute gastroenteritis; Stool culture): Incorrect. Acute gastroenteritis may cause vomiting and diarrhoea, but it does not typically present with red currant jelly stools, a palpable mass, or Dance sign. Stool culture would be used to diagnose infections but is not relevant here.

Option D (Malrotation with volvulus; Upper GI contrast study): Incorrect. Malrotation with volvulus can cause abdominal pain and vomiting, but it typically does not present with red currant jelly stools or a palpable mass. An upper GI contrast study may help diagnose malrotation but is not the best choice for this presentation.

Intussusception: Classic Triad: Sudden onset of episodic abdominal pain, vomiting, and red currant jelly stools (blood and mucus).

  • Dance Sign: Absence of bowel sounds or mass in the right lower quadrant, replaced by a palpable mass.
  • Sausage Shaped Mass: Often palpable in the right upper quadrant or epigastrium.
  • Red Currant Jelly Stools: Indicative of ischemia and mucosal sloughing.

Diagnosis:

  • Ultrasound: Preferred imaging modality; reveals the "target sign" or "doughnut sign."
  • Radiography (Barium or Air Enema): Diagnostic and therapeutic; reveals the "coiled spring sign."

Management:

  • Non Surgical Reduction: Air or barium enema is the treatment of choice, with success rates of over 70%.
  • Surgical Intervention: Indicated if nonsurgical reduction fails, if there are signs of perforation, or if the patient is unstable.

Tags:

Topic: Pediatric Surgery, Intussusception

Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 17, page  number:260

choices.text: Malrotation with volvulus; Upper GI contrast study

questions.text: A 3-week-old male infant presents with projectile nonbilious vomiting after feeding, a palpable olive-shaped mass in the right upper quadrant, and visible peristalsis. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the best diagnostic tool to confirm it?
questions.solution:
Option A (Gastroesophageal reflux disease [GERD]; Barium meal): Incorrect. GERD can present with vomiting, but projectile nonbilious vomiting, a palpable olive-shaped mass, and visible peristalsis are classic features of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (HPS). Barium meal is not the primary diagnostic tool for GERD.

Option B (Hirschsprung disease; Rectal biopsy): Incorrect. Hirschsprung disease typically presents with failure to pass meconium and abdominal distension rather than projectile vomiting and a palpable mass. Diagnosis is confirmed with a rectal biopsy, but this is not the likely diagnosis in this case.

Option C (Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis; Ultrasound): Correct. Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is the most likely diagnosis, given the characteristic clinical features (projectile vomiting, palpable olive-shaped mass, visible peristalsis). Ultrasound is the preferred diagnostic tool and can confirm the diagnosis by measuring pyloric muscle thickness and channel length.

Option D (Malrotation with volvulus; Upper GI contrast study): Incorrect. While malrotation with volvulus can cause vomiting and abdominal pain, it does not typically present with a palpable mass or visible gastric peristalsis. An upper GI contrast study is used to diagnose malrotation but is not the best choice for this case.

Management:

  • Initial Stabilization:
    • Correction of Dehydration and Electrolyte Abnormalities: Use IV fluids with normal saline and potassium to correct metabolic alkalosis.
    • Surgical Treatment:
    • Ramstedt’s Pyloromyotomy: The standard treatment, where the hypertrophic pyloric muscle is cut longitudinally while preserving the mucosa.

Key Points:

  • Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (HPS) is the most common cause of vomiting in infants and involves hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, leading to gastric outlet obstruction.
  • Clinical features include projectile nonbilious vomiting, a palpable olive-shaped mass, visible gastric peristalsis, and metabolic alkalosis.

Tags:

Topic: Hypertrophic Pyloric Stenosis

Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 17, "Pediatric Surgery," page number :260.

choices.text: Observation and follow-up until the age of 2 years
Surgical intervention (orchidopexy) before 18 months of age

questions.text: A 1-year-old male is diagnosed with an undescended testis on physical examination. What is the most appropriate management approach for this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A (Observation and follow-up until the age of 2 years): Incorrect. While some undescended testes may descend spontaneously in the first few months of life, waiting until the age of 2 years for surgery is generally not recommended. Early intervention is preferred to prevent complications such as infertility or testicular malignancy.

Option B (Surgical intervention [orchidopexy] before 18 months of age): Correct. The most appropriate treatment for undescended testis is surgical intervention, typically orchidopexy, to bring the testis into the scrotum. It is ideally performed before the age of 18 months to minimize the risk of infertility and other complications.

Option C (Hormonal therapy to stimulate descent): Incorrect. Hormonal therapy (e.g., human chorionic gonadotropin or GnRH) has been used in some cases, but it is less effective than surgery and is generally not the first-line treatment for undescended testes.

Option D (Immediate orchiectomy): Incorrect. Orchiectomy (removal of the testis) is not indicated for a non-palpable undescended testis unless there is evidence of malignancy or if it remains non-repairable. The goal is to preserve the testis whenever possible.

Key Points:

  • Undescended testis (cryptorchidism) is a condition where one or both testes fail to descend into the scrotum.Surgical management (orchidopexy) is recommended ideally before the age of 18 months to ensure normal testicular function and minimize the risk of infertility and malignancy.

Tags:

Topic: Undescended Testis

Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter 17 page number:256

choices.text: Stabilization with a sterile dressing and gradual reduction of the contents
Insertion of a nasogastric tube for decompression

questions.text: A newborn is diagnosed with omphalocele, What is the most important management step in the immediate postnatal period?
questions.solution:
Option A (Immediate surgical repair): Incorrect. Immediate surgical repair is typically not performed in the neonatal period due to the high risk of infection and the need for initial stabilization of the baby. The hernia is usually repaired once the infant is stable.

Option B (Stabilization with a sterile dressing and gradual reduction of the contents): Correct. The initial step involves stabilizing the newborn with a sterile dressing to protect the exposed organs and gradual reduction of the contents into the abdominal cavity. This is done after ensuring the infant is stable and before surgical repair is attempted.

Option C (Insertion of a nasogastric tube for decompression): Incorrect. While NG tube placement may be necessary to prevent aspiration and decompress the stomach, it is not the immediate management step for an omphalocele.

Option D (Immediate total parenteral nutrition (TPN) administration): Incorrect. TPN may be needed for nutrition in cases of large omphaloceles, but it is not a first-line management step in the immediate postnatal period. The priority is initial stabilization.

Key Points:

  • Omphalocele is a congenital defect in which abdominal contents protrude into the umbilical cord, covered by a membrane.
  • Initial management involves stabilizing the neonate, protecting the protruding organs with a sterile dressing, and gradually reducing the contents before planning for surgical repair.

Tags:

Topic: Omphalocele

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Part 2, Chapter 18, Page Number:270.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient presents with abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and weight loss. His diagnosis of Crohn's disease is confirmed. Based on the Montreal classification of Crohn's disease, which of the following is the most appropriate classification for this patient who has inflammation limited to the ileum?
questions.solution:
Option A (A2B1L1): Correct. Based on the Montreal classification, this patient's age 25years (A2), he has an inflammatory behavior (B1), and the disease is localized to the ileum (L1). The presence of perianal disease does not change the primary classification but can be mentioned as a separate feature.

Option B (A2B2L2): Incorrect. This would indicate a diagnosis between 17-40 years (A2), with stenosing behavior (B2), and colonic involvement (L2). The patient's disease is ileal (L1), and the behavior is inflammatory (B1), not stenosing (B2).

Option C (A3B3L1): Incorrect. This classification would suggest the disease onset after age 40 (A3) and a penetrating behavior (B3), which is inconsistent with the patient's age and the disease presentation.

Option D (A2B1L3): Incorrect. This would classify the disease as occurring between 17-40 years (A2), with an inflammatory behavior (B1), and ileocolonic involvement (L3), but the patient only has ileal involvement (L1).

Montreal Classification of Crohn's Disease

Tags:

Topic: Crohn's Disease, Montreal Classification

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 75 , page number. -1329

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with chronic mesenteric ischemia presents with abdominal pain and weight loss. Imaging reveals a blockage in the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA). Which of the following collateral circulations would be most likely to compensate for this obstruction?
questions.solution:
Option A (Marginal artery of Drummond): Incorrect. While the marginal artery of Drummond runs along the mesenteric margin of the colon and provides collateral circulation, it is more commonly a backup route if the larger arteries, such as the superior or inferior mesenteric arteries, become obstructed. However, it is not the primary compensation route when the IMA is blocked.

Option B (Arc of Riolan - Meandering mesenteric artery): Correct. The Arc of Riolan is a collateral branch that connects the superior mesenteric artery to the inferior mesenteric artery. If the IMA is obstructed, the flow from the superior mesenteric artery can provide retrograde flow through this collateral, compensating for the obstruction.

Option C (Superior mesenteric artery): Incorrect. The superior mesenteric artery (SMA) supplies the cecum and 2/3 of the transverse colon. It does not directly compensate for an obstruction in the inferior mesenteric artery.

Option D (Cecocolic junction): Incorrect. The cecocolic junction is a site of connection between the cecum and the colon, and while it is involved in the blood supply of the colon, it does not act as a primary collateral circulation for the IMA obstruction.

Key Points:

  • Griffith's point: Located in the splenic flexure of the colon (most common site of ischemic colitis)
  • Sudeck's point: Located at the rectosigmoid junction.

Tags:

Topic: Mesenteric Circulation, Abdominal Ischemia

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 77, page number. 1354

choices.text: Thiersch anal wiring (using silastic or nylon tape)

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with rectal prolapse presents for surgical management. Given his frailty and advanced age, which of the following is the most appropriate surgical approach for rectopexy?
questions.solution:
Option A (Rectopexy via abdominal approach): Incorrect. While abdominal rectopexy (e.g., Wells, Ripstein, or Abdominal procedures) is often preferred for younger patients with good overall health, this approach is associated with higher morbidity, making it less ideal for elderly and frail patients.

Option B (Rectopexy via perineal approach): Correct. The perineal approach is typically used in elderly and frail patients due to its lower morbidity and is associated with a higher recurrence rate but a more suitable option for this patient’s condition.

Option C (Resection rectopexy - Frykman Goldberg procedure): Incorrect. While this procedure involves both resection and rectopexy, it is typically reserved for patients with significant rectal prolapse and not generally recommended for frail, elderly patients, making it less suitable for this case.

Option D (Thiersch anal wiring): Incorrect. Thiersch anal wiring is typically used for anal sphincter repair and is not a first-line option for rectal prolapse treatment. It is used for preventing recurrence of prolapse rather than rectopexy itself.

Key Takeaways:

  • Rectopexy via abdominal approach is preferred in younger, healthier patients due to decreased recurrence rates but is associated with higher morbidity.
  • Rectopexy via perineal approach is ideal for elderly and frail patients due to lower morbidity, despite a slightly higher recurrence rate.

Tags:

Topic: Rectal Prolapse, Surgical Management

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 79, page number. -1397

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a history of diverticulitis presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain, fever, and vomiting. On examination, the abdomen is tender with signs of peritonitis. A CT scan reveals a pelvic abscess. Based on the clinical presentation and imaging, which of the following is the most appropriate classification for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Option A (Grade I - Mesenteric or pericolic abscess): Incorrect. This grade is typically associated with abscesses located in the mesentery or pericolic region, not specifically in the pelvic region as seen in this patient.

Option B (Grade II - Pelvic abscess): Correct. This patient's CT scan showing a pelvic abscess with fever and signs of peritonitis fits the description of Grade II, which involves abscess formation in the pelvic region.

Option C (Grade III - Purulent peritonitis): Incorrect. Purulent peritonitis refers to a generalized infection of the peritoneal cavity with pus, typically more diffuse than a localized pelvic abscess.

Option D (Grade IV - Faecal peritonitis): Incorrect. Faecal peritonitis is a more severe form of peritonitis caused by the release of fecal matter into the peritoneal cavity, often due to a rupture of a hollow organ, which is not the case here.

Hinchey Classification of Complicated Diverticulitis


Tags:

Topic: Diverticulitis, Abdominal Abscess

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 77, page number. -1369.

choices.text: Sexual dysfunction with preserved bladder function
Bladder dysfunction with no sexual dysfunction

questions.text: A 45-year-old male undergoes pelvic surgery for a colorectal malignancy. During the procedure, the surgeon inadvertently injures the pelvic plexus nerve fibers. Based on the described injury, which of the following is the most likely clinical feature associated with this complication?
questions.solution:
Option A (Retrograde ejaculation): Incorrect. Retrograde ejaculation is typically caused by injury to the superior hypogastric plexus, leading to sympathetic dysfunction. This occurs with high IMA ligation but is not directly associated with erectile dysfunction and bladder dysfunction as described here.

Option B (Erectile dysfunction and atonic bladder): Correct. Injury to the pelvic plexus and nervi erigentes (as seen with division of the lateral stalks near the pelvic sidewall) results in both erectile dysfunction and bladder dysfunction (atonic bladder).

Option C (Sexual dysfunction with preserved bladder function): Incorrect. The injury described involves both sexual and bladder dysfunction, not just sexual dysfunction.

Option D (Bladder dysfunction with no sexual dysfunction): Incorrect. This scenario would be less likely based on the described injury. Both sexual dysfunction and bladder dysfunction are typically seen together in such cases.

Tags:

Topic: Pelvic Surgery, Nerve Injury, Erectile Dysfunction

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-79, page number. -1413

choices.text: Conservative management with fluid resuscitation and observation
Surgical intervention with closure of fistula tract

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a recent abdominal surgery develops an enterocutaneous fistula (ECF). The output of the fistula is 550 cc/day, and the defect involves the ileal wall with a tract length of 1.5 cm. His serum albumin level is 2.0 g/l, and he presents with open abdomen and signs of sepsis. Based on the presented information, which of the following is the most likely management approach?
questions.solution:
Option A (Conservative management with nutritional build-up): Incorrect. The presence of a high-output fistula (> 500 cc/day) and open abdomen with signs of sepsis makes conservative management inadequate. The patient requires surgical intervention in this context.

Option B (Immediate surgical intervention): Correct. This patient's high-output enterocutaneous fistula (> 500 cc/day), low albumin level (< 2.5 g/l), and open abdomen with sepsis indicate that surgical management, which includes planned surgery as per the SNAP principle, is the most appropriate choice.

Option C (Conservative management with fluid resuscitation and observation): Incorrect. While fluid resuscitation is important, the presence of a high-output fistula and other complicating factors such as sepsis requires surgical management rather than mere observation.

Option D (Surgical intervention with closure of fistula tract): Incorrect. Immediate closure may not be feasible without addressing underlying factors like infection, nutritional status, and anatomical delineation. Surgical management may involve a more comprehensive approach.

Enterocutaneous Fistula Types and Probability of Closure

  • Types:
    • High output: > 500 cc/day
    • Low output: < 200 cc/day

Tags:

Topic: Enterocutaneous Fistula, Management, SNAP Principle

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 74 , page number. 1315

choices.text: Type I: Ulcer located at the incisura angularis
Type II: One ulcer in the stomach body and one in the first part of the duodenum
Type III: Prepyloric ulcer, located just before the pylorus

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with epigastric pain and a history of long-term pain medication. On endoscopy, an ulcer is found on the lesser curvature of the stomach. Based on the classification of gastric ulcers, which type is most consistent with this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Option A (Type I: Ulcer located at the incisura angularis): Incorrect. Type I ulcers are the most common and are located at the incisura angularis, which is not consistent with NSAID-induced ulcers. These are typically located on the lesser curvature.

Option B (Type II: Two ulcers, one in the body of the stomach and one in the first part of the duodenum): Incorrect. Type II ulcers involve both the stomach and the duodenum, but the patient's presentation with NSAID use points to a different classification.

Option C (Type III: Prepyloric ulcer, located just before the pylorus): Incorrect. Type III ulcers are located near the pylorus, but this patient's NSAID use points more toward a Type V ulcer.

Option D (Type V: NSAIDs-induced ulcer): Correct. Type V ulcers are caused by NSAIDs and can be located in various regions, often on the lesser curvature, consistent with the patient's history of NSAID use.

Modified Johnson's Classification of Gastric Ulcers


Key Points:

  • Type II to Type IV are associated with blood group 'O'
  • In Type I, IV, V
    • The acid secretion is either normal or low
    • So, vagotomy is not performed
  • In Type II, III
    • There is increased acid secretion (hypersecretion)
    • Truncal vagotomy is routinely done

Tags:

Topic: Gastric Ulcer Classification, NSAIDs

Reference: Sabiston textbook of surgery 21th edition page number. 1207

choices.text: Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC); alcohol, smoking, and GERD
Adenocarcinoma; GERD, high-fat diet, and Barrett's oesophagus
Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC); alcohol, smoking, and high-fat diet
Adenocarcinoma; smoking, ingested carcinogens, and Barrett's oesophagus

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol use and smoking presents with dysphagia, heartburn, and regurgitation. His endoscopy shows a columnar-lined oesophagus with an abnormal squamous-to-columnar transformation. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what are the key contributing risk factors?
questions.solution:
Option A (Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC); alcohol, smoking, and GERD): Incorrect. SCC is more commonly associated with smoking, alcohol, and ingested carcinogens, but GERD is a major risk factor for adenocarcinoma, not SCC.

Option B (Adenocarcinoma; GERD, high-fat diet, and Barrett's oesophagus): Correct. Barrett's oesophagus, which occurs due to chronic GERD, predisposes to adenocarcinoma. The high-fat diet is another contributing factor for this type of cancer.

Option C (Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC); alcohol, smoking, and high-fat diet): Incorrect. SCC does not commonly result from GERD or Barrett's oesophagus. Alcohol, smoking, and high-fat diet are risk factors for SCC, but not for adenocarcinoma.

Option D (Adenocarcinoma; smoking, ingested carcinogens, and Barrett's oesophagus): Incorrect. While smoking and ingested carcinogens are risk factors for SCC, they are less relevant to adenocarcinoma compared to GERD and Barrett's oesophagus.

Key Takeaways:

  • Barrett's oesophagus is a precursor to adenocarcinoma, primarily associated with GERD.
  • SCC is commonly related to alcohol, smoking, and ingested carcinogens, but not GERD.

Tags:

Topic: Esophageal Cancer

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 66, page number. -1136.

choices.text: Boerhaave syndrome; Mackler's triad (vomiting, chest pain, subcutaneous emphysema)
Mallory-Weiss tear; perforation of the oesophagus

questions.text: A 45-year-old alcoholic male presents with sudden onset of severe chest pain and vomiting after a bout of vomiting. He is found to have signs of subcutaneous emphysema. What is the most likely diagnosis, and what is the key differentiating feature from the other condition?
questions.solution:
Option A (Mallory-Weiss tear; upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage): Incorrect. Mallory-Weiss tear typically presents with upper gastrointestinal bleeding, often after vomiting, but without the signs of perforation, subcutaneous emphysema, or chest pain seen in Boerhaave syndrome.

Option B (Boerhaave syndrome; Mackler's triad): Correct. Boerhaave syndrome involves a full-thickness rupture of the oesophagus, presenting with severe chest pain, vomiting, and subcutaneous emphysema. The classic "Mackler’s triad" includes vomiting, chest pain, and subcutaneous emphysema, which is a key distinguishing feature from Mallory-Weiss tear.

Option C (Mallory-Weiss tear; perforation of the oesophagus): Incorrect. Mallory-Weiss tear involves a tear in the mucosal and submucosal layers of the oesophagus but does not cause perforation or the associated emphysema as seen in Boerhaave syndrome.

Option D (Boerhaave syndrome; upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage): Incorrect. While Boerhaave syndrome can sometimes present with some bleeding, it is characterized more by perforation and the systemic signs of sepsis, not primarily by upper gastrointestinal hemorrhage.

Key Takeaways:

  • Boerhaave syndrome presents with Mackler's triad (vomiting, chest pain, and subcutaneous emphysema) due to esophageal perforation.

Tags:

Topic: Boerhaave syndrome

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 66, page number -1128
